Topic.Title: AAPL buy point

Message.Msg: Nobody really knows, and nobody can catch the exact bottom. If you feel comfortable with the company's financials, believe it has good prospects and can tolerate the risk, you may buy from here. If not, you may just wait. Personally I think the upside potential is much greater than the downside risk now. The overall sentiment is already pretty negative. Whoever bought high and wanted to sell most likely have already sold. Cook said they're contemplating a cash distribution plan. I don't think that's a stalling tactic but a reality. The plan should be revealed soon - March or April. Once that happens, the stock might be on a slingshot upwards. The board meeting is in next week.

Message.Title: Borrowing for buybacks would actually INCREASE cash flow for Apple. Here is why.
Message.Msg: Apple could borrow long-term at an after-tax rate of less than 3%. If you multiply that by the current stock price of $430, that is $12.90 per share. Dividends are currently being paid at $10.60 per share, but that is set to increase in August. Assuming a conservative 10% growth rate, dividends paid out would be roughly the same in only a yer and a half from now, growing indefinitely higher. Since the borrowing rate can be locked in for 30 years, you're talking about some serious cash savings for Apple. And if a repatriation tax holiday every occurs, Apple can easily retire the debt. Why not do this with such rock-bottom stock prices?

Topic.Title: For the longs only --- Do you think AAPL will reach lower than $420 ? I think $420 or $425 is the lowest.

Message.Msg: I`ve been flat and just day trading AAPL since 550. Below is a post I made on Dec. 16 when the stock was trading in the 510-520 range. The post is long and technical and you can read it if you wish, but I will summarize the main point. The POTENTIAL ultimate bottom from my technical perspective at that time was 340. That`s right, 340. That is extreme and unlikely, but possible. At the time I thought 450 as a bottom was a long shot but certainly not out of the question, and here we are even lower at 430. If, and I say if, AAPL is being accumulated now by "smart money", then there should be strong rejection at support and resistance in the 435-465 zone. This doesn`t mean it can`t breach those areas, but if it is truly being accumulated before another up trend, you should see strong buying and strong selling at the opposite ends of this trading range. 425 would fill that old gap, 420 would be the overshoot. If we don`t see some hard bounces (springs) down in this area that get ridden up steadily to the 465 zone before being pushed back down after some shoot through upthrust, then this consolidation has just been the pause before the next leg down. It seems like 425-420 should be the area that will get firmly rejected and spring it back into the accumulation zone, from where it should eventually break out to the upside and test 520 again. Unfortunately 400 is also licking its chops like a begging dog hoping that crumb will drop from the table. The downward momentum has been unbelievably strong and it might not be over. Here`s Dec 16 post talking about bullish divergences: You are right BUT here`s the scary thing: Since the crash of 2008, 14RSI of 29-30 has been the bottom and has always announced a big reversal and somewhat extensive run up. But this fall from 700 has been beating all downside records held since 2008 when it comes to technicals, percentages and swiftness of fall from a top. Looking at the chart and RSI, yes it seems we should bounce up Monday a la double bottom with RSI in bullish divergence formation (Nov 8 RSI 23.9 PPS 538 -- Dec 14 RSI 31.3 PPS 509, i.e., price lower but RSI higher). And we just might, and that might be the end of the fall. And yes the RSI is right at the usual bounce point, BUT like I said, this fall has been setting new post-2008 records. AND this is where it even gets worse RSI wise: A bullish divergence, just like a bearish divergence can take a while to fully mature after the first empirical sign is given. Case in point: Sept 17 2008 AAPL hit an astounding RSI low of 17.1 at a price or 128. Oct 9 2008 it showed a clear bullish divergence with an RSI of 22.5 and a price 89. Nov 20 2008 the bullish convergence reached maturity with an RSI of 33.7 and a price of 80--meaning from there the trend reversed turned up for a long time. But from the RSI low to the final low of the price and completion of the bullish diversion was a change of 37%. If something similar were to happen now, it would imply an ultimate bottom of 340. I don`t think this will happen, but if this divergence takes a little more time to mature as it often does, a bottom of 450 is not out of the question. We could get a nice bounce Monday into the 520s even if it opens down. But these days the unexpected is more the expected. It is also very rare that AAPL gaps down 3 days in a row without the 3rd day bouncing up and closing higher. But again, these tax-selling-ain`t-seen-this-since-2008 days are confounding at best and anything can happen. GLTA disclaimer: I have only been doing this for less than a year--so consider all my info for entertainment purposes only. If I had known what I know now, it would have been a lot easier to see the 700 top and big fall coming as it was a screaming bearish divergence on the 14RSI that took one month to mature--August 20 to Sept 19. Unfortunately, I didn`t realize just how long it takes for this stuff to take root in your mind and ring the bell of reason when your own sentiment has gone postal euphoric, bubbling naiveté and carving out the trenches of denial. Even so, I do hope we go up soon. Less

Message.Title: In Defense of Einhorn?
Message.Msg: I write the title with a question mark because either he knows what he is doing or he doesnt. But there are a few unassailable facts to consider: All of AAPL's supply and manufacturing victories over the last few years are attributable to Cook. It's no easy task and the best days of AAPL had Cook working hard to keep the supply-demand lines flowing. So when there were serious supply disruptions, obviously Cook had to work on that. Think about it. The iMac issue was huge and looking at January's data has been corrected. iMac sales are up huge. You have to imagine that being responsible for that end of the business for so long, Cook took it personal and concentrated on working on that. Perhaps to the exclusion of other areas of interest (including the stock price). As for the dividend issue, let's get this out of the way first: FKUC Einhorn. That iPrefs plan is a mess and does not help any of us common shareholders long term. There is no way Cook could move with that hanging in the air. It would make the company look reactionary to stock price movements, which no company (ever) wants to do. Besides, the 1 year anniversary of the dividend announcement is up and that would be a much more appropriate time for an announcement than the ASM. I almost think it is better for Cook to let the stock drop a bit more so that AAPL can buy back shares on the cheap. Unless you are playing with options or you have a time a horizon less than a few years, this isn’t a problem. No one wants to see the stock price go down. But if AAPL can get the shares cheaper and at the same time I get a chance to buy cheaper then it’s worth it. I'm willing to hold AAPL long term and every drop from here on in is another chance to buy more at a cheaper price. So I wouldn't worry too much about the stock price if you really bought the stock (not calls!)l. Opportunities like this don't come around often in the market. Take it or leave it.

Message.Title: CNBC is not the Problem - It's Apple
Message.Msg: Apple has provided these cynical , sacastic, and unprofessional talking heads with fodder to bash and sensationalize every rumor , or rumor of a rumor. Apple, through its silence has let the rumors, about sales, profits, supply chain events , fester, and take hold..... CNBC also had nothing to do with the stock dropping 75 points while Tim Cook was speaking at the first quarter earnings call and the GS technical conference. Tim Cook has opened the door to uncertainties which feeds speculation. He never adequately explained lost sales due to supply restrictions, he never provided updates on correcting the map fiasco, or the decision to prematurely launch the program..... He just never explains anything , that could be explained, without disclosing trade secrets. Tim has created a vacuum , which has become a playground for CNBC, The media, and bloggers. Apple has become a hook, circus act, and draw for CNBC........ Apple opened the door...... Yes , some of the segments, guests, and positions are off the wall and absurd, and providing a platform for self-serving traders like Kass , border on unethical..... But it sells....... And Apple provides the vehicle. The only one who can move the needle and improve the perception is APPLE...... And the company may need another spokesperson to turn the tide. If Apple does not change it ways, and recognize perception counts, they will not be be #1 on the most admired list in 2013......

Topic.Title: In Defense of Einhorn?

Message.Msg: Doubtful AAPL is going private any time soon. The company has to be in serious trouble for that (see Dell). The truth is that not much has changed for AAPL except that they have hit the law of large numbers. It's almost impossible for them to keep growing at the rate they were growing before as they have already passed the GNP's of a lot of nations. So now comes the turn into a stable dividend paying stock. Boring but profitable long term. Raising the dividend at this point denies the company the chance to buy the shares back cheaper. If they do buy the shares at the cheapest price possible, then EPS and other metrics will look even better a year from now. AAPL is an amazing company with a helluva product. The computers are kick butt (if expensive) and the ecosystem is one of a kind. When people enter the AAPL world they usually don't go back to the PC or Samsung world. The ecosystem builds on itself. In my case, I bought an Ipod Shuffle the other day and finally figured out how to get US iTunes (I live in South Korea) and downloaded T.I. 'The Paper Trail' full album. Right there is about $75 dollars to AAPL in about 10 minutes. It adds up. If someone bought at $700 then they overpaid. True. If someone is playing with margin then good luck to them as that is not investing. But in the end, value trap or not, AAPL is as worth the gamble of investing your money with a 5-10 year time horizon as any stock out there.

Message.Title: Yahoo to shut down seven products, including Blackberry app
Message.Msg: Yahoo Inc is shutting down seven products, including its mobile app for Blackberry smartphones, as new Chief Executive Marissa Mayer takes a page from Google Inc's Playbook by eliminating unsuccessful products en masse. The product shutdowns, which Yahoo announced on its official company blog on Friday, are part of what the company said are regular efforts to evaluate and review its product lineup. "The most critical question we ask is whether the experience is truly a daily habit that still resonates for all of you today," wrote Jay Rossiter, Yahoo's executive vice president of Platforms. The announcement represents Yahoo's second group shutdown of products since Mayer, a former Google executive, became CEO of the struggling Web portal in July. So-called "spring cleaning" announcements, in which multiple products are shut down, have become a regular feature at Google in recent years. Mayer signaled the company would prune its line-up of mobile apps at an investor conference last month, noting that Yahoo would reduce the 60 to 75 disparate mobile apps it currently has to a more manageable 12 to 15 apps. Yahoo said its app for Blackberry smartphones would no longer be available for download, or supported by Yahoo, as of April 1. Yahoo also said that on April 1 it will stop supporting Yahoo Avatars - the cartoon-like digital characters that consumers create to depict them on Web services such as Yahoo instant messenger and Facebook. Consumers who want to continue using their avatar on Yahoo's online services must download the avatar and then re-upload the information to their personalized Yahoo profile. The other Yahoo products set to be terminated include Yahoo App Search, Yahoo Sports IQ, Yahoo Clues, the Yahoo Message Boards website and the Yahoo Updates API.

Message.Title: The wait for an iPhone may finally be over this year for customers on the China Mobile TD-LTE network, reports Patently Apple.
Message.Msg: TD-LTE service by Steven Sande Mar 1st 2013 at 6:30PM. The wait for an iPhone may finally be over this year for customers on the China Mobile TD-LTE network, reports Patently Apple. China Mobile confirmed at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona this week that it will be running tests of its TD-LTE network in more than 100 cities in China, which will provide fast data service to a potential customer base of more than 500 million people. The news follows reports that Apple supplier Qualcomm is producing a new solution that supports all available LTE implementations and that would allow phone manufacturers to provide a single mobile device that would provide global LTE roaming support. If Apple chooses to use this solution -- which also provides more efficient use of battery power -- in an upcoming iPhone, it could open the door to even more dynamic growth in sales of Apple's flagship product.

Message.Title: Apple iPhone 6 Targets China Mobile in Bid for Supremacy in Smartphone Wars
Message.Msg: Apple iPhone 6 Targets China Mobile in Bid for Supremacy in Smartphone Wars By Fiona Keating: Subscribe to Fiona's RSS feed March 2, 2013 3:17 PM GMT There are rumours that iPhone 6 orders have already been placed with the manufacturers at Foxconn and could be ready for a release in August Apple's next smartphone could be sold by China Mobile later this year, in a bold attempt to capitalise on the Chinese market of 500 million people. According to Chinese news site EMSOne, Apple's latest iPhone will be designed to work on the TD-LTE 4G high-speed mobile network of China Mobile - China's largest carrier. In fact, the iPhone 6 - unlike the current iPhone 5 - will be compatible with all 4G networks worldwide. Analysts have been predicting that Apple's wilting share price is unlikely to recover unless the Cupertino-based electronics giant can make inroads with consumers in China, whose market is almost twice the size of that in the United States. Apple's iPhone 5 sales continuing to be healthy, but the company's stock is now down 19 percent this year. AppleInsider reported that Barclays Capital analysts claim that iPhone 6 orders have already been placed with the manufacturers at Foxconn and that the new phone could be ready for release in August.

Topic.Title: The wait for an iPhone may finally be over this year for customers on the China Mobile TD-LTE network, reports Patently Apple.

Message.Msg: Here is some related info from "The Appleinsider": Rumor: Apple to ship 'iPhone 5S' and more affordable iPhone in August 2013 By AppleInsider Staff Apple reportedly plans to build a more affordable iPhone model this August alongside launch a new world mode "iPhone 5S" featuring compatibility with China Mobile, the largest carrier in the world. The details were reported on Friday by Chinese tech news site EMSOne (translation), which cited analysts from Barclays Capital. It claimed that a "cheap edition" of the iPhone will be built this year by both Foxconn, Apple's usual manufacturing partner, as well as Pegatron. The report suggests that Foxconn will also be the exclusive manufacturer of Apple's next-generation "iPhone 5S." It was not indicated that Pegatron had received any orders for the company's next flagship handset. Unlike the current iPhone 5, which requires different models for separate carriers with unique LTE frequencies, the so-called "iPhone 5S" is expected to be a world phone that will add compatibility with new carriers, including China Mobile. That ability could be aided by Qualcomm's latest LTE chipset, which operates on 40 bands, including all existing LTE networks. China Mobile, which has nearly 700 million total subscribers, utilizes an obscure TD-SCDMA network that is incompatible with the current iPhone 5. As for the cheaper iPhone, Friday's report claimed it will not be a world phone, and will only support the frequency division duplex (FDD) flavor of LTE. China Mobile's network uses time division duplexing (TDD) for its LTE network. The report comes on the heels of a separate one out of Japan issued on Thursday, which claimed that Apple is planning to cut costs by building its next iPhone out of polycarbonate, similar to the company's retired white MacBook. It was said that Apple plans to charge around $330 without a service contract for its entry-level iPhone. Tags:FoxconnPegatroniPhone 5SiPhone miniJump to comments (30) Categories:

Message.Title: Mini-options will start trading March 18 to screw up share price even more
Message.Msg: Wall Street crooks will make sure AAPL share price never bounce back. Go short is the only way to win. Watch and Learn “As options’ popularity has grown among retail traders over the last decade, the exchanges have responded with more products. Weekly options, introduced in 2005, have gained to the point that the top options-centric online brokers report that they comprise almost half of their options volume this year,” Theresa W. Carey reports for Barron’s. “Most expect weekly options to pass regular monthly options in volume this year.” “On March 18, the exchanges will introduce mini-options on three high-priced active stocks and two exchange-traded funds: Apple (ticker: AAPL), Google (GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) and SPDR Gold ETF (GLD),” Carey reports. “All of these equities are priced well over $100 per share, which makes it tough for most retail investors to buy them in 100-share blocks. The new mini-options will make them more affordable—representing just 10 shares of stock.” Carey reports, “Under the traditional 100-share terms, near-the-money April calls for Apple, for example, are in the $15-$20 range for a contract, so a single call option could set you back about $2,000. If you were to write a covered call — buying 100 shares of Apple and selling the April 440 strike — you’d be looking at a price tag of over $42,000. Investors could wait for a stock split or two to make these pricey stocks easier to buy, but they’d have to wait a long time. So to keep the little guy involved, mini-options are coming.”

Message.Title: Let’s put Apple’s amazing cash on hand numbers into perspective
Message.Msg: he company now has $137.1 billion in cash — a 12.9 percent increase from the last reported number, $121.3 billion. With such a big figure, it’s hard to realize how big it actually is. Message.Msg: As many of the experts and analysts on CNBC and elsewhere have stated, then for hypothetical let's say 2014 & 2015 earnings drop 50% to around $22-25/share. Currently the overall market average for P/E is 17 so if we also discount that to say 10, which is a huge, huge discount then the future earnings of $23.50 times 10 equals 235 Billion in market cap for the business, hugely discounted, ONLY. Now, if you add in the existing cash balance, about 137 billion as of 12/31/2012 but more likely 150 billion by now, that gets you to share price of about $410/share. Thats at HUGE discounts and doesn't include the annuity effects of the dividend or dividend increases or potential positive business developments like new products or China Mobile sales or strategic acquisition that may be accretive to earnings quickly or not quickly. And then there is no debt so no forward interest rate risk for refinancing in later years either. If they can execute then there is nowhere to go but up, eventually. Big if, yes, but if thats what you think then you have to be in. I'm trying to add at $50 (since about 525) intervals as AAPL has declined and days like Friday get discouraging but it'll have to find a bottom somewhere not too much lower and if its got to go to 400, 375 or even 350 then so be it because eventually the underlying value will be realized. This is all about momentum right now just like the run ups in stocks like NFLX and LNKD and many others that don't even have any fundamentals. Cheers.

Topic.Title: If AAPL Decline is Based on Fears of Margin Compression & Futures Earnings Concerns

Message.Msg: I don't think that's what's keeping it down. Too many people buying options, not enough interested in holding the stock... as long as money managers can make more from expired options than they can from holding the stock, there will be downward pressure. AAPL's cash isn't worth dollar value, it's only worth what people are willing to pay for it. Since much is locked up in foreign cash, and AAPL seems reluctant to do anything with it or distribute a large portion of it, people are not willing to pay full price for it. AAPL is undervalued; I assume it'll take until all the suckas who are losing money on options are all burned out before it'll return to proper valuation... who knows how long that will take. I'd buy if you think holding the stock long term is worth it at current prices. I wouldn't recommend buying based on trying to figure out what others will do to the stock, because the street thrives on the failed expectations of investors. --- Noob trying to sound like I know what I'm talking about.

Message.Title: How AAPL should address shareholder concerns.
Message.Msg: As long as buying options seems like a better bet than owning the stock, the options sellers can keep driving the price down. Part of the problem is that the stock seems too expensive to own, for a lot of investors. A 10-to-1 stock split would make the price $43.05, which is easier for people to swallow and justify owning. Second, if the stock is truly undervalued in the eyes of Apple board, a large buyback would be a good investment for the company and would help restore some confidence. Third, an increase in dividend would make holding the stock more attractive. Investors no longer see AAPL as a sure-thing growth stock like they did last year. Apple needs to either prove that they're still that (and they can't, if the market doesn't react "properly"), or they have to become more shareholder friendly. A split should be painless, buybacks seem smart, and an increased dividend might be necessary. All 3 together should appease shareholders.

Message.Title: iTunes U...
Message.Msg: Here's my prediction - iTunes U is going to cause a revolution in quality on-line education. Apple is putting together on-line courses with a wide consortium of prestigious university professors that includes lectures, books, quizzes...you get the picture. They will transform the on-line industry much like they transformed the music industry. The public good is incredible when you can bring quality on-line college educational courses with professors from Duke, Yale, MIT, Oxford and others to the masses (currently for free) via their laptop. Forget the jokester on-line degrees from University of Phoenix!! iTunes U is offering top notch quality on-line courses for free! I suspect this will evolve into on-line programs for nominal fees which will be shared by the participating universities and Apple much like music industry was transformed by Apple. Over one billion and counting for this transformatiional program. Not everyone has access to a quality education for a truly affordable price, but I think in time iTunes U is putting together a truly world class on-line educational platform that will become the gold standard for on-line college courses. I just don't see how any university or for-profit company could compete with the quality on its own if iTunes gets a large consortium of presitigious universities.
